intro: Gaylussacia thymelaeoides, commonly known as the swamp blueberry, is a deciduous shrub native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the Ericaceae family, which includes many shrubs and small trees adapted to acidic soils. The plant produces small, bell-shaped white flowers in the spring, which are followed by dark blue berries in the summer. Its leaves are elliptical and turn red in the fall, adding to its ornamental value. The species is often found in wetlands and bogs, where it plays a role in maintaining ecosystem health.
